title: How can businesses use technology to improve the customer feedback experience? - Quora

response.answer_text: As you’d know, the ultimate aim to improve customer feedback experience is to be able to retain customers and improve the product or service being offered. With proper customer feedback data, there are three things that you can do: Develop and improve on a product or serviceUnderstand the level of customer satisfaction to deliver a useful product or serviceKnow and plan the steps for improvements (of the product and customer experience, in effect) While surveys, calls, and questionnaires do help in getting direct customer feedback, it is important for a business to understand customer behavior in depth. When we talk about technology helping a business improve overall, why shy away from getting a bigger deal? The customer analytics tools we have today not only help in getting direct customer feedback through surveys but they also have several other features to help you with your business decisions. I would like to list down some solutions for you along with some of their features in brief: Exponea Exponea is a cloud-based solution that helps in customer analytics and behavior predictions. You can profile your customers on the basis of their activity history online across devices and create attribution models of your customers. The software also lets you send out quick surveys to your customers and get actionable insights to retain them. You can customize and personalize your communication with the customers through websites and banners. Some other features to look out for include Exponea’s ability to support A/B test for online campaigns, generate comprehensive reports and automate marketing newsletters. Pricing: On request.  Google Analytics Google Analytics is a web analytics platform. It provides analytics around audience, content, mobile, social, conversion, advertising, cross-device data, and events. Its custom reports help you to understand the user-interaction on your website and let you affect end-user behavior with engaging communication through ads, videos, integrated social tools and website content. Google Analytics also allows you to collaborate data from other systems including CRM to give a consolidated view regarding customer feedback. I suggest that you check out the features of this tool in detail here to understand what all you can do to improve your business with Google Analytics. You can monitor customer activity, analyze costs, analyze customers, extract and filter data, track defects, manage eCommerce and get real-time analytics. ClicData integrates well with SurveyMonkey, Twitter, Google Analytics and Facebook to help you get, collate and improve customer feedback. Some of the other features relevant to customer analytics and business management include capacity for predictive analysis, integration with multiple data sources, data manipulation and sales analytics. Most businesses don’t address the issue here. Technology is great because it can make statistically significant conclusions and record the results for you without having to do it manually - but they almost always require customers to give feedback AFTER they have left the restaurant. The problem with online surveys is that the customer needs to remember to do the survey at home on their computer. Furthermore, their memories of the experience may be hazy and there has never been a clear motivation to give feedback. Most restaurants that use this get under 30 reviews a month, which is more often than not less than 1% of their customers. Technology needs to be used INSIDE the restaurant. Companies like Buzzer provide innovative point of sale solutions that let the customer fill out the survey in the restaurant on a tablet or their own mobile phone. This increases the quality and volume of feedback whilst still providing managers with the valuable data automatically, and costs far less than you’d think!

There are quite a number of ways a business can use technology to improve the customer feedback experience. Surveys One obvious way to improve the customer feedback experience is to utilize an online survey tool that your customers won’t mind or even enjoy using. It’s also important to prompt surveys at the right times to your customers that makes sense for the product/service you provide. Often times I see businesses bombarding website visitors with survey prompts which can be off-putting. Survey55 (https://www.survey55.com) is one of a few solutions in the survey category (note: I’m the founder) Live Chat The major obvious difference between surveys and live chat, is that with live chat you’re talking with a specific customer. Usually live chat is used to give real-time support and possible gather customer feedback. It’s a good way to engage with a customer. Check out Zendesk Chat Email (email automation) A proactive way of improving the customer feedback experience is to send personalized emails based on a customer’s action(s). For example, when you onboard a new customer, perhaps send an email that answers one or two frequent questions in the form of “tips”. For an e-commerce business, one thing you could do is combine email automation with a survey: When a customer buys something, have an automated email sent when their item ships that contains a survey asking them about their buying experience. Mailchimp has pretty decent email automation platform that we use. There are probably a few more categories I could talk about, but these are probably a good way to start off to cover most of your scenarios. One thing I like to briefly highlight is mobile. It seems that customer feedback isn’t talked about as much when it comes to mobile businesses vs web, however it’s just as important. This is one of the reasons why also full support native mobile apps with Survey55.

A small example : Before the time of smartphone, your consumer needs to write down their feedback then send it via postal service to you or go to your office then manually filling the feedback form which requires some amount of time and resources. That often makes the customer hesitant to give their feedback, which lead to less feedback and less accurate information for you. Now in the time smartphone, you can deliver the feedback form to their smartphone and they will spend much smaller resources to fill it because they can do it whenever and wherever they are. They will be more willingly to give feedback because it is so much easier to do and spend much smaller resources which will lead to more feedback and more accurate information for you.

1. By measuring customer feedback - the way to start improving customer feedback is to first measure it. A lot of companies, even now, either don't measure feedback at all or use old ways (like paper feedback forms) to understand customer sentiment and feedback. By using a customer feedback software and app, you can digitize the method in which your customers share their feedback with you. Why this helps? Well, for many reasons - you get real-time feedback, you can set up alerts for bad feedback, you don't have to manually collate feedback, feedback reporting becomes automatic, you can reach your customers anywhere - through tablet, email feedback, SMS feedback, online and more. 2. By staying updated of negative feedback - You can use the customer feedback software to set up alerts for bad feedback and use technology to be updated of all issues - all in real-time. 3. By reaching out to customers, instantly - A good customer feedback tool will give you the ability to email your customers instantly and connect with them to close the feedback loop. 4. By sending automated emails to customers based on their feedback - You can also use technology, in this case a customer feedback software, to set up automated emails to miffed customers and to happy customers, based on their feedback. By measuring feedback and taking action, businesses can really shorten their turn around time for complaints and improve customer feedback. It’s funny how customer feedback is also often referred to as “Voice of the Customer”, yet very few businesses use exactly this source - voice. One way in which businesses can improve customer feedback experience is to stop asking and start listening. Phone calls are still a reality for most giants out there, but few companies utilize their call recordings for anything other than compliance backup. In the meantime, customers are sharing an abundance of information during calls. They will casually remark on your pricing, products, offer, service, particular locations, campaigns, touch points, website performance, customer service. All businesses have to do is listen and collect. I know the reason why most don’t. For a long time speech analytics was expensive, a nightmare to onboard, and well, not particularly accurate. However, in the last 5 years voice-related technology made a bigger progress than in previous two decades (just as Siri). At the moment basic speech analytics programs can jot down the content of the conversation with accuracy above 80% and deliver something that no survey will capture: emotion. Human voice is chock-full of it, and it can be used a source of some mind-blowing business intelligence.  This is a screengrab of the conversation captured by a voice processing engine called EVS. It contains some basic call parameters: transcript, speaker id, time of call, emotion. The companies who use it don’t even look at files like the one above, just feed it into analytical engines that combine thousands of calls to figure out things like keywords, topics/agents/prices/offers that get the most negative/positive ratings. What’s more - every opinion can be traced back to a customer who has given it, and checked for context. So how to make customer feedback experience better? Stop surveying, start paying attention.
